1;San Marco Cathedral;"The Patriarchal Cathedral Basilica of Saint Mark (Italian: Basilica Cattedrale Patriarcale di San Marco)
column2: commonly known as St Mark's Basilica (Italian: Basilica di San Marco
column3: Venetian: BaxÇ?ega de San Marco)
column4: is the cathedral church of the Roman Catholic Patriarchate of Venice
column5: it became the episcopal seat of the Patriarch of Venice in 1807
column6: replacing the earlier cathedral of San Pietro di Castello. It is dedicated to and holds the relics of Saint Mark the Evangelist
column7: the patron saint of the city.

column1: The church is located on the eastern end of Saint Mark's Square
column2: the former political and religious centre of the Republic of Venice
column3: and is attached to the Doge's Palace. Prior to the fall of the republic in 1797
column4: it was the chapel of the Doge and was subject to his jurisdiction
column5: with the concurrence of the procurators of Saint Mark de supra for administrative and financial affairs.

column1: The present structure is the third church
column2: begun probably in 1063 to express Venice's growing civic consciousness and pride. Like the two earlier churches
column3: its model was the sixth-century Church of the Holy Apostles in Constantinople
column4: although accommodations were made to adapt the design to the limitations of the physical site and to meet the specific needs of Venetian state ceremonies. Middle-Byzantine
column5: Romanesque
column6: and Islamic influences are also evident
column7: and Gothic elements were later incorporated. To convey the republic's wealth and power
column8: the original brick faáades and interior walls were embellished over time with precious stones and rare marbles
column9: primarily in the thirteenth century. Many of the columns
column10: reliefs
column11: and sculptures were spoils stripped from the churches
column13: and public monuments of Constantinople as a result of the Venetian participation in the Fourth Crusade. Among the plundered artefacts brought back to Venice were the four ancient bronze horses that were placed prominently over the entry.

column1: The interior of the domes
column2: the vaults
column3: and the upper walls were slowly covered with gold-ground mosaics depicting saints
column4: prophets
column5: and biblical scenes. Many of these mosaics were later retouched or remade as artistic tastes changed and damaged mosaics had to be replaced
column6: such that the mosaics represent eight hundred years of artistic styles. Some of them derive from traditional Byzantine representations and are masterworks of Medieval art
column7: others are based on preparatory drawings made by prominent Renaissance artists from Venice and Florence
column8: including Paolo Veronese
column9: Tintoretto
column10: Titian

column1: 2;San Marco square;"Piazza San Marco often known in English as St Mark's Square
column2: is the principal public square of Venice
column3: Italy
column4: where it is generally known just as la Piazza (""the Square""). All other urban spaces in the city (except the Piazzetta and the Piazzale Roma) are called campi (""fields""). The Piazzetta (""little Piazza/Square"") is an extension of the Piazza towards San Marco basin in its south east corner (see plan). The two spaces together form the social
column5: religious and political centre of Venice and are commonly considered together";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;P.za San Marco;NULL

column1: 3;Palazzo Ducale;"The Doge's Palace (Italian: Palazzo Ducale
column2: Venetian: Pa?aso Dogal) is a palace built in Venetian Gothic style
column3: and one of the main landmarks of the city of Venice in northern Italy. The palace was the residence of the Doge of Venice
column4: the supreme authority of the former Republic. It was built in 1340 and extended and modified in the following centuries. It became a museum in 1923 and is one of the 11 museums run by the Fondazione Musei Civici di Venezia.

column1: In 810
column2: Doge Agnello Participazio moved the seat of government from the island of Malamocco to the area of the present-day Rialto
column3: when it was decided a palatium duci (Latin for ""ducal palace"") should be built. However
column4: no trace remains of that 9th-century building as the palace was partially destroyed in the 10th century by a fire. The following reconstruction works were undertaken at the behest of Doge Sebastiano Ziani (1172?1178). A great reformer
column5: he would drastically change the entire layout of the St. Mark's Square. The new palace was built out of fortresses
column6: one faáade to the Piazzetta
column7: the other overlooking the St. Mark's Basin. Although only few traces remain of that palace
column8: some Byzantine-Venetian architecture characteristics can still be seen at the ground floor
column9: with the wall base in Istrian stone and some herring-bone pattern brick paving.

column1: By the end of the 19th century
column2: the structure was showing clear signs of decay
column3: and the Italian government set aside significant funds for its restoration and all public offices were moved elsewhere
column4: with the exception of the State Office for the protection of historical Monuments
column5: which is still housed at the palace's loggia floor. In 1923
column6: the Italian State
column7: owner of the building
column8: entrusted the management to the Venetian municipality to be run as a museum. Since 1996
column9: the Doge's Palace has been part of the Venetian museums network
column10: which has been under the management of the Fondazione Musei Civici di Venezia since 2008.";09:00:00;19:00:00;25;P.za San Marco

column1: 4;Canale Grande;"The Grand Canal (Italian: Canal Grande
column2: Venetian: Canal Grando
column3: anciently Cana?asso) is a channel in Venice
column4: Italy. It forms one of the major water-traffic corridors in the city.

column1: One end of the canal leads into the lagoon near the Santa Lucia railway station and the other end leads into the basin at San Marco
column2: in between
column3: it makes a large reverse-S shape through the central districts (sestieri) of Venice. It is 3.8 km (2.4 mi) long
column4: and 30 to 90 m (98 to 295 ft) wide
column5: with an average depth of 5 metres (16 feet).

column1: The banks of the Grand Canal are lined with more than 170 buildings
column2: most of which date from the 13th to the 18th century
column3: and demonstrate the welfare and art created by the Republic of Venice. The noble Venetian families faced huge expenses to show off their richness in suitable palazzos
column4: this contest reveals the citizens? pride and the deep bond with the lagoon. Amongst the many are the Palazzi Barbaro
column5: Ca' Rezzonico
column6: Ca' d'Oro
column7: Palazzo Dario
column8: Ca' Foscari
column9: Palazzo Barbarigo and to Palazzo Venier dei Leoni
column10: housing the Peggy Guggenheim Collection. The churches along the canal include the basilica of Santa Maria della Salute. Centuries-old traditions
column12: are perpetuated every year along the Canal.

column1: Because most of the city's traffic goes along the Canal rather than across it
column2: only one bridge crossed the canal until the 19th century
column3: the Rialto Bridge. There are currently three more bridges
column4: the Ponte degli Scalzi
column5: the Ponte dell'Accademia
column6: and the controversial Ponte della Costituzione from 2008
column7: designed by Santiago Calatrava
column8: connecting the train station to Piazzale Roma
column9: one of the few places in Venice where buses and cars can enter. As was usual in the past
column10: people can still take a ferry ride across the canal at several points by standing up on the deck of a simple gondola called a traghetto
column11: although this service is less common than even a decade ago.

column1: Most of the palaces emerge from water without pavement. Consequently
column2: one can only tour past the fronts of the buildings on the grand canal by boat.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;NULL;NULL

column1: 5;Ponte di Rialto;"The Rialto Bridge (Italian: Ponte di Rialto
column2: Venetian: Ponte de Rialto) is the oldest of the four bridges spanning the Grand Canal in Venice
column3: Italy. Connecting the sestieri (districts) of San Marco and San Polo
column4: it has been rebuilt several times since its first construction as a pontoon bridge in 1173
column5: and is now a significant tourist attraction in the city.

column1: The first dry crossing of the Grand Canal was a pontoon bridge built in 1181 by Nicolï Barattieri. It was called the Ponte della Moneta
column2: presumably because of the mint that stood near its eastern entrance.

column1: The development and importance of the Rialto market on the eastern bank increased traffic on the floating bridge
column2: so it was replaced in 1255 by a wooden bridge. This structure had two ramps meeting at a movable central section
column3: that could be raised to allow the passage of tall ships. The connection with the market eventually led to a change of name for the bridge. During the first half of the 15th century
column4: two rows of shops were built along the sides of the bridge. The rents brought an income to the State Treasury
column5: which helped maintain the bridge.

column1: Maintenance was vital for the timber bridge. It was partly burnt in the revolt led by Bajamonte Tiepolo in 1310. In 1444
column2: it collapsed under the weight of a crowd rushing to see the marriage of the Marquis of Ferrara and it collapsed again in 1524.

column1: The idea of rebuilding the bridge in stone was first proposed in 1503. Several projects were considered over the following decades. In 1551
column2: the authorities requested proposals for the renewal of the Rialto Bridge
column3: among other things. Plans were offered by famous architects
column4: such as Jacopo Sansovino
column5: Palladio and Vignola
column6: but all involved a Classical approach with several arches
column7: which was judged inappropriate to the situation. Michelangelo also was considered as designer of the bridge.

column1: The present stone bridge
column2: a single span designed by Antonio da Ponte
column3: began to be constructed in 1588 and was completed in 1591. It is similar to the wooden bridge it succeeded. Two ramps lead up to a central portico. On either side of the portico
column4: the covered ramps carry rows of shops. The engineering of the bridge was considered so audacious that architect Vincenzo Scamozzi predicted future ruin. The bridge has defied its critics to become one of the architectural icons
column5: and top tourist attractions
column6: in Venice.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;Sestiere San Polo

column1: 6;Torre dell'Orologio;"The Clock Tower in Venice is an early Renaissance building on the north side of the Piazza San Marco
column2: at the entrance to the Merceria. It comprises a tower
column3: which contains the clock
column4: and lower buildings on each side. It adjoins the eastern end of the Procuratie Vecchie. Both the tower and the clock date from the last decade of the 15th century
column5: though the mechanism of the clock has subsequently been much altered. It was placed where the clock would be visible from the waters of the lagoon and give notice to everyone of the wealth and glory of Venice. The lower two floors of the tower make a monumental archway into the main street of the city
column6: the Merceria
column7: which linked the political and religious centre (the Piazza) with the commercial and financial centre (the Rialto). Today it is one of the 11 venues managed by the Fondazione Musei Civici di Venezia.

column1: On a terrace at the top of the tower are two great bronze figures
column2: hinged at the waist
column3: which strike the hours on a bell. One is old and the other young
column4: to show the passing of time and
column5: although said to represent shepherds (they are wearing sheepskins) or giants (they are huge figures of great mass
column6: necessary so that their form can be recognized at a distance) they are known as ""the Moors"" because of the dark patina acquired by the bronze. The bell is also original and is signed by Simeone Campanato
column7: who cast it at the Arsenal in 1497.[1]

column1: Below this level is the winged Lion of Saint Mark with the open book
column2: before a blue background with gold stars. There was originally a statue of the Doge Agostino Barbarigo (Doge 1486?1501) kneeling before the lion
column3: but in 1797
column4: after the city had surrendered to Napoleon
column5: it was removed by the French
column6: who were purging the city of all symbols of the old regime.[2]

column1: Below again
column2: is a semi-circular gallery with statues of the Virgin and Child seated
column3: in gilt beaten copper. On either side are two large blue panels showing the time: the hour on the left in Roman numerals and the minutes (at 5 minute intervals) on the right in Arabic numerals. Twice a year
column4: at Epiphany (6 January) and on Ascension Day (the Thursday 40 days after Easter
column5: counting both days)
column6: the three Magi
column7: led by an angel with a trumpet
column8: emerge from one of the doorways normally taken up by these numbers and pass in procession round the gallery
column9: bowing to the Virgin and child
column10: before disappearing through the other door.

column1: Below this is the great clock face in blue and gold inside a fixed circle of marble engraved with the 24 hours of the day in Roman numerals. A golden pointer with an image of the sun moves round this circle and indicates the hour of the day. Within the marble circle beneath the sun pointer are the signs of the zodiac in gold (these are original and date from the 1490s)
column2: which revolve slightly more slowly than the pointer to show the position of the sun in the zodiac. In the middle of the clockface is the earth (in the centre) and the moon
column3: which revolves to show its phases
column4: surrounded by stars which are fixed in position. The background is of blue enamel. The smaller blue circles in the four corners are not now used.

column1: Below the clock is the archway
column2: two storeys high
column3: through which the street known as the Merceria leaves the Piazza on its way to the Rialto (This section of the Merceria is known as the Merceria dell'Orologio (of the clock)).

column1: The buildings on each side have been let off separately as shops and apartments since the early 18th century.
On the other side of the tower
column2: there is another great clock face above the arch
column3: visible to people walking down the street towards the Piazza. This is a simpler affair
column4: again surrounded by a marble circle marked with the 24 hours
column5: but in two series of 12 hours each. The sun pointer
column6: marking the hours
column7: is the only moving part on this side.";11:00:00;14:00:00;12;P.za San Marco

column1: 7;Teatro la Fenice;"Teatro La Fenice (""The Phoenix"") is an opera house in Venice
column2: Italy. It is one of ""the most famous and renowned landmarks in the history of Italian theatre"" and in the history of opera as a whole. Especially in the 19th century
column3: La Fenice became the site of many famous operatic premieres at which the works of several of the four major bel canto era composers ? Rossini
column4: Bellini
column5: Donizetti
column6: Verdi ? were performed.

column1: Its name reflects its role in permitting an opera company to ""rise from the ashes"" despite losing the use of three theatres to fire
column2: the first in 1774 after the city's leading house was destroyed and rebuilt but not opened until 1792
column3: the second fire came in 1836
column4: but rebuilding was completed within a year. However
column5: the third fire was the result of arson. It destroyed the house in 1996 leaving only the exterior walls
column6: but it was rebuilt and re-opened in November 2004. In order to celebrate this event the tradition of the Venice New Year's Concert started.

column1: Seven old theaters were active in Venice at the end of the eighteenth century
column2: two for the production of plays and the others for music. The grandest of these was the Teatro San Benedetto
column3: which stood on the site currently occupied by the Rossini cinema. Built by the Grimani family in 1755
column4: it was subsequently assigned to the Nobile SocietÖ di Palchettisti (Noble Association of Box-holders). However
column5: following a judicial ruling in 1787
column6: this association was expelled and forced to give up the opera house to the noble Venier family
column7: the owners of the land on which it was built. The association immediately proposed building a larger and more sumptuous opera house than the one it had lost
column8: which would become the symbol of their changing fortunes and their capacity for ?rebirth?. It was therefore to be called La Fenice
column9: like the mythical
column10: immortal bird able to rise out of its own ashes
column11: to symbolise the association's splendid rebirth after its misfortunes.

column1: The piece of land between Contrada Santa Maria Zobenigo and Contrada Sant'Angelo was bought for the purpose in 1790 and the private houses on it were demolished. A competition was then announced for the design of the opera house
column2: and the committee of experts selected the work of the architect Giannantonio Selva from the 29 plans submitted. Work began in 1791 and was completed just 18 months later
column3: in April 1792. La Fenice immediately made its mark as one of the leading opera houses
column4: noted in Italy and Europe both for the high artistic quality of its work and the splendour of its building. But
column5: almost as if the name were the bearer of bad omens
column6: on the night of 13 December 1836 the opera house was devastated by a first fire caused by a recently installed Austrian heater. The newspapers said it took three days and three nights to put out the fire and that various hotspots were still smouldering among the debris 18 days later. The flames entirely destroyed the house
column7: and only the foyer and the Sale Apollinee were saved. The association decided to proceed with its immediate reconstruction. It appointed the architect Giambattista Meduna and his engineer brother Tommaso to carry out the work
column8: while Tranquillo Orsi was responsible for the decorations. The work began in February 1837 and performances were temporarily staged in the Teatro Apollo (previously the San Luca
column9: now Goldoni).

column1: Everything was completed in record time. By the evening of 26 December of the same year
column2: the new opera house
column3: reborn in the new artistic style of the age
column4: was opened to the public. The speed of the work
column5: however
column6: led to urgent restoration works to the framework being required as early as 1854 and
column7: again under the direction of Giambattista Meduna
column8: the house was redecorated in a style that remained unchanged until 1996. On 23 July 1935 the box-holder owners ceded their share in the opera house to the Comune di Venezia
column9: so it went from private to public ownership
column10: and in 1937-8 part of building was subject to further major restorations and alterations by engineer Eugenio Miozzi. On the night of 29 January 1996
column11: during a period of closure for restoration works
column12: a second fire ? as the Myth said ? this time arson
column13: completely destroyed the house and most of the Sale Apollinee. Once again La Fenice rose again
column14: faithfully reconstructed to a plan by the architect Aldo Rossi
column15: and was reopened on 14 December 2003.";09:30:00;23:00:00;0;Campo S. Fantin

column1: 8;Ca' d'Oro;"The Ca' d'Oro or Palazzo Santa Sofia is a palace on the Grand Canal in Venice
column2: northern Italy. One of the older palaces in the city
column3: its name means ""golden house"" due to the gilt and polychrome external decorations which once adorned its walls. Since 1927
column4: it has been used as a museum
column5: as the Galleria Giorgio Franchetti.

column1: It has long been regarded as the best surviving palazzo in Venetian Gothic architecture
column2: retaining all the most characteristic features
column3: despite some losses. On the facade
column4: the loggia-like window group of closely spaced small columns
column5: with heavy tracery with quatrefoil openings above
column6: uses the formula from the Doge's Palace that had become iconic. There are also the byzantine-inspired decoration along the roofline
column7: and patterning in fancy coloured stone to the flat wall surfaces. The smaller windows show a variety of forms with an ogee arch
column8: capped with a relief ornament
column9: and the edges and zone boundaries are marked with ropework reliefs.

column1: The third act of Amilcare Ponchielli's opera La gioconda is set in the palace.
The palace was built between 1428 and 1430 for the Contarini family
column2: who provided Venice with eight Doges between 1043 and 1676. The architects of the Ca d'Oro were Giovanni Bon and his son Bartolomeo Bon.

column1: Following the fall of the Venetian Republic in 1797
column2: the palace changed ownership several times. In 1846
column3: Alessandro Trubetzkoi
column4: purchased the palace
column5: which was in a ruinous state
column6: as a gift for ballet dancer Marie Taglioni. The reckless renovation of the architect resulted in his imprisonment under charges of vandalism. In the end
column7: many of the Gothic features
column8: including the stairway of the inner courtyard and the balconies which overlooked the courtyard
column9: were removed.

column2: the palace was acquired by its last owner
column3: baron Giorgio Franchetti
column4: throughout his lifetime
column5: he amassed an important art collection and personally oversaw its extensive restoration
column6: including the reconstruction of the stairway and the Cosmatesque courtyard with ancient marbles. In 1916
column7: Franchetti bequeathed the Ca' d'Oro to the Italian State. It is now open to the public as a gallery: Galleria Giorgio Franchetti alla Ca' d'Oro.";08:15:00;18:00:00;11;Calle Ca' d'Oro

column1: 9;Murano e Burano;"The island was probably settled by the Romans
column2: and in the 6th century was occupied by people from Altino
column3: who named it for one of the gates of their former city. Two stories are attributed to how the city obtained its name. One is that it was initially founded by the Buriana family
column4: and another is that the first settlers of Burano came from the small island of Buranello
column5: about 8 kilometres (5 miles) to the south.

column1: Although the island soon became a thriving settlement
column2: it was administered from Torcello and had none of the privileges of that island or of Murano. It rose in importance only in the 16th century
column3: when women on the island began making lace with needles
column4: being introduced to such a trade via Venetian-ruled Cyprus.[6] When Leonardo da Vinci visited in 1481
column5: he visited the small town of Pano Lefkara and purchased a cloth for the main altar of the Duomo di Milano. The lace was soon exported across Europe
column6: but trade began to decline in the 18th century and the industry did not revive until 1872
column7: when a school of lacemaking was opened. Lacemaking on the island boomed again
column8: but few now make lace in the traditional manner as it is extremely time-consuming and therefore expensive.

column1: Murano was initially settled by the Romans and from the sixth century by people from Altinum and Oderzo. At first
column2: the island prospered as a fishing port and through its production of salt. It was also a centre for trade through the port it controlled on Sant'Erasmo. From the eleventh century
column3: it began to decline as islanders moved to Dorsoduro. It had a Grand Council
column4: like that of Venice
column5: but from the thirteenth century
column6: Murano was ultimately governed by a podestÖ from Venice. Unlike the other islands in the Lagoon
column7: Murano minted its own coins.

column1: Early in the second millennium hermits of the Camaldolese Order occupied one of the islands
column2: seeking a place of solitude for their way of life. There they founded the Monastery of St. Michael (Italian: S. Michele di Murano). This monastery became a great center of learning and printing. The famous cartographer
column3: Fra Mauro
column4: whose maps were crucial to the European exploration of the world
column5: was a monk of this community. The monastery was suppressed in 1810 by French forces under Napoleon
column6: in the course of their conquest of the Italian peninsula
column7: and the monks were expelled in 1814. The grounds then became Venice's major cemetery.

column2: all the glassmakers in Venice were required to move to Murano.[2] In the following century
column3: exports began
column4: and the island became famous
column5: initially for glass beads and mirrors. Aventurine glass was invented on the island
column6: and for a while Murano was the main producer of glass in Europe. The island later became known for chandeliers. Although decline set in during the eighteenth century
column7: glassmaking is still the island's main industry.

column1: In the fifteenth century
column2: the island became popular as a resort for Venetians
column3: and palaces were built
column4: but this later declined. The countryside of the island was known for its orchards and vegetable gardens until the nineteenth century
column5: when more housing was built.

column1: Attractions on the island include the Church of Santa Maria e San Donato (known for its twelfth-century Byzantine mosaic pavement and said to house the bones of the dragon slain by Saint Donatus in the 4th century)
column2: the church of San Pietro Martire with the chapel of the Ballarin family built in 1506 and artworks by Giovanni Bellini
column3: and the Palazzo da Mula. Glass-related attractions include the many glassworks
column4: some Mediaeval and most open to the public
column5: and the Murano Glass Museum
column6: housed in the large Palazzo Giustinian.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;NULL;NULL

column1: 10;Peggy Guggenheim Collection;"The Peggy Guggenheim Collection is a modern art museum on the Grand Canal in the Dorsoduro sestiere of Venice
column2: Italy. It is one of the most visited attractions in Venice. The collection is housed in the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni
column3: an 18th-century palace
column4: which was the home of the American heiress Peggy Guggenheim for three decades. She began displaying her private collection of modern artworks to the public seasonally in 1951. After her death in 1979
column5: it passed to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation
column6: which opened the collection year-round from 1980.

column1: The collection includes works of prominent Italian futurists and American modernists working in such genres as Cubism
column2: Surrealism and abstract expressionism. It also includes sculptural works. In 2017
column3: Karole Vail
column4: a granddaughter of Peggy Guggenheim
column5: was appointed Director of the collection
column6: succeeding Philip Rylands
column7: who led the museum for 37 years.

column1: The collection is principally based on the personal art collection of Peggy Guggenheim
column2: a former wife of artist Max Ernst and a niece of the mining magnate
column3: Solomon R. Guggenheim. She collected the artworks mostly between 1938 and 1946
column4: buying works in Europe ""in dizzying succession"" as World War II began
column5: and later in America
column6: where she discovered the talent of Jackson Pollock
column7: among others. The museum ""houses an impressive selection of modern art. Its picturesque setting and well-respected collection attract some 400
column8: 000 visitors per year""
column9: making it ""the most-visited site in Venice after the Doge's Palace"". Works on display include those of prominent Italian futurists and American modernists. Pieces in the collection embrace Cubism
column10: Surrealism and abstract expressionism. During Peggy Guggenheim's 30-year residence in Venice
column11: her collection was seen at her home in the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni and at special exhibitions in Amsterdam (1950)

column1: The collection is housed in the Palazzo Venier dei Leoni
column2: which Peggy Guggenheim purchased in 1949.[1] Although sometimes mistaken for a modern building
column3: [9] it is an 18th-century palace designed by the Venetian architect Lorenzo Boschetti.[10] The building was unfinished
column4: and has an unusually low elevation on the Grand Canal.";10:00:00;18:00:00;14;Dorsoduro

column1: 11;Gallerie dell'Accademia;"The Gallerie dell'Accademia is a museum gallery of pre-19th-century art in Venice
column2: northern Italy. It is housed in the Scuola della CaritÖ on the south bank of the Grand Canal
column3: within the sestiere of Dorsoduro. It was originally the gallery of the Accademia di Belle Arti di Venezia
column4: the art academy of Venice
column5: from which it became independent in 1879
column6: and for which the Ponte dell'Accademia and the Accademia boat landing station for the vaporetto water bus are named. The two institutions remained in the same building until 2004
column7: when the art school moved to the Ospedale degli Incurabili.

column1: The Accademia di Belle Arti di Venezia was founded on 24 September 1750
column2: the statute dates from 1756. The first director was Giovanni Battista Piazzetta
column3: Gianbattista Tiepolo became the first president after his return from WÅrzburg.

column1: It was one of the first institutions to study art restoration starting in 1777 with Pietro Edwards
column2: and formalised by 1819 as a course.

column1: In 1807 the academy was re-founded by Napoleonic decree. The name was changed from Veneta Academia di Pittura
column2: Scultura e Architettura to Accademia Reale di Belle Arti
column3: ""royal academy of fine arts""
column4: and the academy was moved to the Palladian complex of the Scuola della CaritÖ
column5: where the Gallerie dell'Accademia are still housed. The collections of the Accademia were first opened to the public on 10 August 1817.

column1: The Gallerie dell'Accademia became independent from the Accademia di Belle Arti di Venezia in 1879. Like other state museums in Italy
column2: it falls under the Ministero per i Beni e le AttivitÖ Culturali
column3: the Italian ministry of culture and heritage.";08:15:00;19:15:00;12;Campo della CaritÖ

column1: 12;Santa Maria dei Miracoli;"Also known as the ""marble church""
column2: it is one of the best examples of the early Venetian Renaissance including colored marble
column3: a false colonnade on the exterior walls (pilasters)
column4: and a semicircular pediment. The organisation Save Venice Inc. restored the church over a period of seven years
column5: from 1990 to 1997 (after several years of preliminary research).[1] The treatments focussed on the marble sheeting and sculptural decoration of both the exterior and interior of the church. The marble cladding contained 14 percent of salts
column6: and was on the point of bursting
column7: when restorers began the desalination and cleaning process. All marble cladding was removed
column8: and cleaned in stainless steel tanks
column9: in a solution of distilled water. Additionally
column10: the campaign worked in the coffered ceiling
column11: which was made up of fifty-two wooden panels depicting saints and prophets. The cleaning led to the rediscovery of frescoes of sibyls on the spandrels of the ceiling. Nearly every part of the church was examined and treated
column12: including the intarsia doors in the presbytery
column13: the bronze statues and candelabra of the high altar
column14: and the wooden panel of the Madonna from which the church got its name. The restoration was calculated to cost 1 million dollars
column15: the final cost was 4 million dollars. The main altar is reached by a series of steps. The circular facade windows recall Donato Bramante's churches in Milan.

column1: Built between 1481 and 1489 by Pietro Lombardo to house a miraculous icon of the Virgin Mary. The plans for the church were expanded in 1484 to include the construction of a new convent for nuns of St. Clare to the east. The convent was connected to the gallery of the church by an enclosed walkway that was later destroyed.
The interior is enclosed by a wide barrel vault
column2: with a single nave. The nave is dominated by an ornamental marble stair rising between two pulpits
column3: with statues by Tullio Lombardo
column4: Alessandro Vittoria and Niccolï di Pietro. The vaulted ceiling is divided into fifty coffers decorated with paintings of prophets
column5: a work by Girolamo Pennacchi's contemporaries
column6: Vincenzo dalle Destre and Lattanzio da Rimini.";10:30:00;17:00:00;3;Campiello dei Miracoli

column1: 13;Ca' Rezzonico;"Ca' Rezzonico is a palazzo on the Grand Canal in the Dorsoduro sestiere of Venice
column2: Italy. It is a particularly notable example of the 18th century Venetian baroque and rococo architecture and interior decoration
column3: and displays paintings by the leading Venetian painters of the period
column4: including Francesco Guardi and Giambattista Tiepolo. It is a public museum dedicated to 18th-century Venice (Museo del Settecento Veneziano) and one of the 11 venues managed by the Fondazione Musei Civici di Venezia.

column1: Ca' Rezzonico stands on the right bank of the canal
column2: at the point where it is joined by the Rio di San Barnaba. The site was previously occupied by two houses
column3: visible in early paintings of Venice in 1500
column4: which a century and a half later were in a sad state of decay. They belonged to the Bon family
column5: one of Venice's patrician clans. In 1649 the head of the family
column6: Filippo Bon
column7: a Procurator of the city and patron of the arts
column8: decided to transform the two houses into a single large palazzo on the site. For this purpose he employed Baldassarre Longhena (1597-1682)
column9: the greatest proponent of Venetian Baroque
column10: a style slowly replacing the Renaissance and Palladian architectural style. Longhena was the designer of the famous dome of the Church of Santa Maria della Salute
column11: a Venice baroque landmark. By 1661 Longhena had combined the two earlier structures
column12: and work had begun on the facade facing the canal
column13: and had reached as high as the first
column16: neither architect nor client was to see the completion of the Palazzo Bon: Longhena died in 1682
column17: and Filippo Bon saw his finances ruined by the cost of the palazzo. He was forced to halt the work.

column1: The facade was finished between 1750 and 1752. Turning his attention to the interior
column2: Massari broke with Venetian custom and put the major ceremonial room at the back of the building
column3: not overlooking the canal. He doubled the height of the ceiling in this room and eliminated walls to create a more dramatic space. He laid out a ceremonial route that would take visitors from the dock and gateway on the Grand Canal to a fountain in the interior courtyard
column4: surmounted by the coat of arms of the Rezzonico in marble
column5: then taking a triumphal hallway to the monumental stairway which took them up to the grand salon or ballroom. As soon as the salons were completed
column6: their ceilings were painted with frescoes by Giovanni Battista Crosato and in trompe-l'?il by Girolamo Mengozzi Colonna.

column1: The interior work was nearly finished in 1756. The pinnacle of the Rezzonico's power and the Palazzo's grandeur came in 1758
column2: when Carlo
column3: the younger brother of Giambattista Rezzonico
column4: was elected Pope as Clement XIII
column5: the same year Ludovico Rezzonico married Faustina Savorgnan
column6: uniting the two richest families in Venice. To mark that occasion
column7: Rezzonico commissioned the most celebrated painter of Venice
column8: the aging Giovanni Battista Tiepolo
column9: to paint the ceilings of two salons
column10: along painters with Gaspare Diziani and Jacopo Guarana.

column1: The palace was the site of further celebrations in 1759
column2: when Aurelio Rezzonico was elected Procurator of San Marco
column3: and in 1762
column4: when Ludovico Rezzonico was elected to the same position. For three nights
column5: the facades and interiors of the palace were lit with torches and candles in celebration. Upon his election as Pope
column6: Carlo Rezzonico transferred a large part of the family art collection from Venice to Rome.";10:00:00;18:00:00;10;Dorsoduro

column1: 14;Isola di Torcello;"Torcello is a sparsely populated island at the northern end of the Venetian Lagoon
column2: in north-eastern Italy. It was first settled in the year 452 and has been referred to as the parent island from which Venice was populated. It was a town with a cathedral and bishops before St Mark's Basilica was built.

column1: After the downfall of the Western Roman Empire
column2: Torcello was one of the first lagoon islands to be successively populated by those Veneti who fled the terra ferma (mainland) to take shelter from the recurring barbarian invasions
column3: especially after Attila the Hun had destroyed the city of Altinum and all of the surrounding settlements in 452. Although the hard-fought Veneto region formally belonged to the Byzantine Exarchate of Ravenna since the end of the Gothic War
column4: it remained unsafe on account of frequent Gothic (Sarmatian) invasions and wars: during the following 200 years the Lombards and the Franks fuelled a permanent influx of sophisticated urban refugees to the island?s relative safety
column5: including the Bishop of Altino himself. In 638
column6: Torcello became the bishop?s official seat for more than a thousand years and the people of Altinum brought with them the relics of Saint Heliodorus
column7: now the patron saint of the island.

column1: Torcello benefited from and maintained close cultural and trading ties with Constantinople: however
column2: being a rather distant outpost of the Eastern Roman Empire
column3: it could establish de facto autonomy from the eastern capital.

column1: Torcello rapidly grew in importance as a political and trading centre: in the 10th century it had a population often estimated at 10
column3: 000 people
column4: with 20
column5: 000 the most commonly cited estimate. However
column6: some recent estimates by archeologists place it at closer to a maximum of 3
column7: 000. In pre-Medieval times
column8: Torcello was a much more powerful trading center than Venice. Thanks to the lagoon?s salt marshes
column9: the salines became Torcello?s economic backbone and its harbour developed quickly into an important re-export market in the profitable east-west-trade
column10: which was largely controlled by Byzantium during that period.

column1: The Black Death devastated the Venice Republic in 1348 and again between 1575 and 1577. In three years
column2: the plague killed some 50
column3: 000 people. In 1630
column4: the Italian plague of 1629?31 killed a third of Venice's 150
column5: 000 citizens. A further serious issue for Torcello specifically was that the swamp area of the lagoon around the island increased by the 14th century
column6: partly because of the lowering of the land level. Navigation in the laguna morta (dead lagoon) was impossible before long and traders ceased calling at the island. The growing swamps also seriously aggravated malaria.

column1: As a result
column2: by the late 14th century
column3: a substantial number of people left the island for Murano
column4: Burano or Venice. In 1689
column5: the bishopric transferred to Murano
column6: and by 1797
column7: the population had dropped to about 300. It now has a full-time population of just 10 people
column8: including the parish priest
column9: according to some sources

column1: 15;Lido di Venezia;"The Lido
column2: or Venice Lido (Italian: Lido di Venezia)
column3: is an 11-kilometre-long (7-mile) barrier island in the Venetian Lagoon
column4: northern Italy
column5: it is home to about 20
column6: 400 residents. The Venice Film Festival takes place at the Lido late August/early September.

column1: The Lido island is one of the two barrier islands of the Lagoon of Venice
column2: the other is Pellestrina. They form the central part of the coastline of the lagoon on the Adriatic Sea. The peninsula of Cavallino/Punta Sabbioni forms the northern part and the peninsula of Sottomarina forms the southern part. The sea has access to the lagoon through three inlets between the islands and between the islands and the peninsulas. At the northern end of Lido there is the Lido inlet which separates it from Cavallino/Punta Sabbioni and at the southern end there is the Malamocco inlet which separates it from Pellestrina.[2] These two inlets have been dredged to a greater depth to allow big ships through. The Malamocco inlet is the deepest one and is used by container ships and oil tankers to reach the commercial and industrial port of Marghera. The Lido inlet is the widest one (c.1 km) and is used by cruise ships to reach Venice.

column1: Lido is a long and narrow island which gets wider in its northern tract. At least half the seaward coast has sandy beaches. Much of the beach at the town of Lido belongs to various hotels. There are large public beaches towards the northern and southern ends.
The island is home to a town and a village. The town is in the north. It is also called Lido (population 15
column2: 128 in 2019). Its neighbourhoods are San Nicolï
column3: Santa Maria Elisabetta
column4: on the lagoon side coast (the landing stage for the Venice ferry is in the former and the one for the water bus is in the latter)
column5: and La Favorita and Quattro Fontane
column6: on the seaward coast. It developed in the 19th century as a tourist centre
column7: both as a leisure seaside resort and as a balneotherapy resort. It has many 19th century villas built in Liberty style (the Italian version of Art Nouveau) and many hotels. It is famous for being the seat of the Venice Film Festival and for its grand hotels
column8: such as the Grand Hotel des Bains
column9: the Hotel Excelsior. and the Hotel Ausonia & Hungaria  which have hosted celebrities
column10: artists and writers
column12: politicians and royalties. The Gran Viale Santa Maria Elisabetta (27 m wide and c. 700 m long) crosses the town from coast to coast and links the water bus landing stage to the beach.

column1: The village of Malamocco (with a population of 1030 as of 2019)is on the lagoon side coast
column2: in the central-southern part of the island. From the 12th century to the 19th century it was the only significant settlement on the island. It was built after the settlement of Metamaucum
column3: which had been the second capital of the Duchy of Venetia
column4: was submerged by a storm surge.

column1: At the southern end of the island is Alberoni
column2: an area of sand dunes. It has Venice's golf course and the Alberoni Dune Oasis which has one of the largest and best-preserved dune systems on the coasts of the Northern Adriatic Sea
column3: with dunes up to 10 meters high
column4: a large
column5: c. 30 hectares
column6: pine forest and unique species of flora and fauna.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;NULL;NULL

column1: 16;Museo Storico Navale;The Museo Storico Navale is a naval history museum located in the Castello district of Venice
column2: near the Venetian Arsenal. The museum was established by the Regia Marina (the Italian Royal Navy) in 1919. Its collections include items relating to the naval and maritime history of Venice
column3: and it has a large number of ship models and weapons on display.;11:00:00;17:00:00;7

column1: 17;La Biennale;"The Venice Biennale is an international cultural exhibition hosted annually in Venice
column2: Italy by the Biennale Foundation. The biennale has been organised every year since 1895
column3: which makes it the oldest of its kind. The main exhibition held in Castello
column4: in the halls of the Arsenale and Biennale Gardens
column5: alternates every second year between art and architecture (hence the name biennale
column6: biannual)
column7: while the other events hosted by the Foundation
column8: spanning theatre
column9: music
column10: and dance
column11: as well as Venice's film festival
column12: are held annually in various parts of Venice.

column1: The Art Biennale (La Biennale d'Arte di Venezia)
column2: is one of the largest and most important contemporary visual art exhibitions in the world. So-called because it is held biannually (in odd-numbered years)
column3: it is the original biennale on which others in the world have been modeled. The exhibition space spans over 7.000 square metres
column4: and artists from over 75 countries are represented in the collective exhibition spaces as well as in the national pavilions.

column1: The Architecture Biennale (La Biennale d'Architettura di Venezia) is held in even-numbered years. Similarly to the Art Biennale
column2: the exhibition is based one main exhibition in the arsenale halls
column3: as well as national exhibitions hosted in the pavilions of the arsenale and Biennale gardens.";00:00:00;00:00:00;21;Forte Marghera;NULL

column1: 19;Il ponte dei Sospire;"The Bridge of Sighs (Italian: Ponte dei Sospiri) is a bridge in Venice
column2: Italy. The enclosed bridge is made of white limestone
column3: has windows with stone bars
column4: passes over the Rio di Palazzo
column5: and connects the New Prison (Prigioni Nuove) to the interrogation rooms in the Doge's Palace. It was designed by Antonio Contino
column6: whose uncle Antonio da Ponte designed the Rialto Bridge
column7: and it was built in 1600.

column1: The view from the Bridge of Sighs was the last view of Venice that convicts saw before their imprisonment. The bridge's English name was bequeathed by Lord Byron in the 19th century as a translation from the Italian ""Ponte dei sospiri""
column2: from the suggestion that prisoners would sigh at their final view of beautiful Venice through the window before being taken down to their cells.

column1: The 1861 opera Le pont des soupirs by Jacques Offenbach has the bridge as a setting.[citation needed]

The Bridge of Sighs features heavily in the plot of the 1979 film A Little Romance. One of the characters tells of a tradition that if a couple kiss in a gondola beneath the Bridge of Sighs in Venice at sunset while the church bells toll
column2: they will be in love forever.

column1: Bridge of Sighs is the name of the second solo studio album released in April 1974 by English rock guitarist and songwriter
column2: Robin Trower
column3: which reached #7 in the United States and certified Gold on 10 September 1974. Although Trower named the album after a racehorse with that name that he saw listed in a sports page
column4: it is generally assumed that the horse was named after the well-known bridge in Venice
column5: Italy.

column1: Marillion
column2: an English progressive rock band
column3: mentions this particular bridge in their song 'Jigsaw'. ('We are renaissance children becalmed beneath the Bridge of Sighs'). Giles Corey
column4: an American slowcore band
column5: likewise mentions this bridge in their song ?No One Is Ever Going To Want Me.?

column1: Renowned American architect H.H. Richardson used the bridge as inspiration when designing part of the Allegheny County Jail complex in Pittsburgh
column2: PA. It was completed in 1888
column3: and features a similar enclosed arched walkway that connects the courthouse and jail
column4: therefore bearing the same name.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;P.za San Marco

column1: 20;Mercati di rialto;"The Rialto market was Venice's most important trading center . The name Rialto derives from the Italian rivo alto = the high bank . It was one of the first places in the lagoon to be settled. From the very beginning
column2: trade and traffic have been concentrated at the Rialto.

column1: Originally the Venice market was held on Saturdays in the large square of Olivolo in Castello . Especially in the early days it was known for having no taxes and other public charges
column2: and in this way it was able to compete with the markets of Pavia and Campalto
column3: then among the most important in Italy. When the government settled here in the 9th century
column4: the Rialto became the driving force behind the development of commerce. The construction of a fish and vegetable market was the visible confirmation of the successful efforts. At the end of the 15th century
column5: apart from a few small ones
column6: there were only three major markets in Venice. On the first Saturday on San Polo
column7: on the second Saturday on San Marco and on the third always on Campo San Giovanni in Bragora
column8: but Rialto always remained the most important trading place. They not only traded al minute
column9: but also handled large batches
column10: set prices
column11: regulated import and export and the chartering of ships. In addition to trading in fish and vegetables
column12: there was a commodity exchange where gold and silver were traded.

column1: The state supervised and directed all these businesses
column2: for trade with the rest of Italy there was the Dogana di Terra
column3: which provided for a levy on every shipment of cloth
column4: every liter of oil
column5: wine
column6: every kilogram of flour
column7: millet or beans. There was the Fondaco della Farina
column8: a large state magazine where families could shop and get supplies
column9: but only for a month to prevent panic buying and speculation . The bakers also stocked up on flour here.

column1: The state rented the merchants uno stazio
column2: an outdoor stand with a banco in front
column3: a wooden shed at the back
column4: and the whole thing covered with a sail. Of course there were also itinerant traders who
column5: unlike the stand owners
column6: did not have to pay any significant taxes and were tolerated by them because their modest trade in eggs
column7: chickens and some vegetables did not represent any competition.

column1: The rigid fixing of food prices
column2: especially fish
column3: prompted the various urban associations to complain about the myriad of administrative regulations
column4: as these made the free movement of goods more difficult. It was only the French
column5: the ""padroni francesi""
column6: in the person of the ""prefetto del Adriatico""
column7: who ordered the Ministry of the Interior to repeal all old structures and regulations in 1807
column8: especially those fixing the maximum price. The motion was accepted on December 15
column10: and the corporations concerned were dissolved.";00:00:00;00:00:00;0;Sestiere San Polo
